questions: What are the twin characteristics of growth?
answers: Increase in mass and increase in number of individuals are the twin characteristics of growth.

questions: What is the difference between the growth of living and non-living things?
answers: In non-living things growth occurs from the outer side whereas in living organisms growth is from the inner side.

questions: What do you understand by the term metabolism?
answers: The sum total of all the chemical reaction occurring in an organism is known as metabolism.

questions: Give any two defining characteristics of living beings.
answers: Metabolism and consciousness are two defining characteristics of living beings.

questions: What does ICBN stand for?
answers: ICBN stands for International code of Botanical Nomenclature.

questions: Define nomenclature.
answers: The system of providing organism with appropriate and distinct names is called nomenclature.

questions: Who is known as the father of Botany?
answers: Theophrastus is known as the father of Botany.

questions: What is the need of taxonomy?
answers: Taxonomy makes the identification of organisms and their study more convenient.

questions: What is biochemical systematics?
answers: The classification of plants and animals on the basis of biochemical characteristics is called biochemical systematics.

questions: Who introduced the term species?
answers: John Ray.

questions: Why are common names not employed in scientific studies?
answers: Common names are used to recognise an organism in different regions of a country. Sometimes one common name is often used for several species.

questions: Who wrote ‘Systema Nature’?
answers: Carolus Linnaeus in 1758.

questions: What is biodiversity?
answers: Biodiversity can be defined as the number and types of organisms present an earth.

questions: What is hierarchy of categories?
answers: It is defined as sequence of categories in a decreasing or increasing order from kingdom to species and vice versa. Kingdom is the highest rank followed by division, Class, Order, Family, Genus and Species.

questions: What is the basic unit of classification?
answers: Species is the unit of classification.

questions: What is the difference between monotypic and polytypic genus?
answers: When genus consist of only one existing species it is called a monotypic genus and when it consist of many species it is said to be as polytypic genus.

questions: How are monographs different from manuals?
answers: Monograph contain information on any one taxon whereas manuals provide information for identification of name of species in an area.
